trans-unit.source: If your app offers a large in-app product catalog, you can optionally follow the process described in this topic to help manage your catalog.
trans-unit.target: If your app offers a large in-app product catalog, you can optionally follow the process described in this topic to help manage your catalog.

trans-unit.source: Manage a large catalog of in-app products
trans-unit.target: Manage a large catalog of in-app products

trans-unit.source: Manage a large catalog of in-app products
trans-unit.target: Manage a large catalog of in-app products

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: If your app offers a large in-app product catalog, you can optionally follow the process described in this topic to help manage your catalog.
trans-unit.target: If your app offers a large in-app product catalog, you can optionally follow the process described in this topic to help manage your catalog.

trans-unit.source: You will create a handful of product entries for specific price tiers, with each one able to represent hundreds of products within a catalog.
trans-unit.target: You will create a handful of product entries for specific price tiers, with each one able to represent hundreds of products within a catalog.

trans-unit.source: To enable this capability, use the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) method overload that specifies an app-defined offer associated with an in-app product listed in the Store.
trans-unit.target: To enable this capability, use the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) method overload that specifies an app-defined offer associated with an in-app product listed in the Store.

trans-unit.source: In addition to specifying an offer and product association during the call, your app should also pass a [**ProductPurchaseDisplayProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263384) object that contains the large catalog offer details.
trans-unit.target: In addition to specifying an offer and product association during the call, your app should also pass a [**ProductPurchaseDisplayProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263384) object that contains the large catalog offer details.

trans-unit.source: If these details are not provided, the details for the listed product will be used instead.
trans-unit.target: If these details are not provided, the details for the listed product will be used instead.

trans-unit.source: The Store will only use the *offerId* from the purchase request in the resulting [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392).
trans-unit.target: The Store will only use the *offerId* from the purchase request in the resulting [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392).

trans-unit.source: This process does not directly modify the information originally provided when [listing the in-app product in the Store](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt148551).
trans-unit.target: This process does not directly modify the information originally provided when [listing the in-app product in the Store](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt148551).

trans-unit.source: **Note** Starting with Windows 10, the Store has no limit to the number of product listings per developer account.
trans-unit.target: **Note** Starting with Windows 10, the Store has no limit to the number of product listings per developer account.

trans-unit.source: In previous releases, the Store has a limit of 200 product listings per developer account, and the process described in this topic can be used to work around that limitation.
trans-unit.target: In previous releases, the Store has a limit of 200 product listings per developer account, and the process described in this topic can be used to work around that limitation.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This topic covers Store support for the representation of multiple in-app offers using a single in-app product listed in the Store.
trans-unit.target: This topic covers Store support for the representation of multiple in-app offers using a single in-app product listed in the Store.

trans-unit.source: If you are unfamiliar with in-app purchases please review [Enable in-app product purchases](enable-in-app-product-purchases.md) to learn about license information, and how to properly list your in-app purchase in the Store.
trans-unit.target: If you are unfamiliar with in-app purchases please review [Enable in-app product purchases](enable-in-app-product-purchases.md) to learn about license information, and how to properly list your in-app purchase in the Store.

trans-unit.source: When you code and test new in-app offers for the first time, you must use the [**CurrentAppSimulator**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779766) object instead of the [**CurrentApp**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779765) object.
trans-unit.target: When you code and test new in-app offers for the first time, you must use the [**CurrentAppSimulator**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779766) object instead of the [**CurrentApp**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779765) object.

trans-unit.source: This way you can verify your license logic using simulated calls to the license server instead of calling the live server.
trans-unit.target: This way you can verify your license logic using simulated calls to the license server instead of calling the live server.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you need to customize the file named "WindowsStoreProxy.xml" in %userprofile%\\AppData\\local\\packages\\<package name>\\LocalState\\Microsoft\\Windows Store\\ApiData.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you need to customize the file named "WindowsStoreProxy.xml" in %userprofile%\\AppData\\local\\packages\\<package name>\\LocalState\\Microsoft\\Windows Store\\ApiData.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Visual Studio simulator creates this file when you run your app for the first time—or you can also load a custom one at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Visual Studio simulator creates this file when you run your app for the first time—or you can also load a custom one at runtime.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see **CurrentAppSimulator**.
trans-unit.target: For more info, see **CurrentAppSimulator**.

trans-unit.source: This topic also references code examples provided in the [Store sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=627610).
trans-unit.target: This topic also references code examples provided in the [Store sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=627610).

trans-unit.source: This sample is a great way to get hands-on experience with the different monetization options provided for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: This sample is a great way to get hands-on experience with the different monetization options provided for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: Make the purchase request for the in-app product
trans-unit.target: Make the purchase request for the in-app product

trans-unit.source: The purchase request for a specific product within a large catalog is handled in much the same way as any other purchase request within an app.
trans-unit.target: The purchase request for a specific product within a large catalog is handled in much the same way as any other purchase request within an app.

trans-unit.source: When your app calls the new [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) method overload, your app provides both an *OfferId* and a [**ProductPurchaseDisplayProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263390) object populated with the name of the in-app product.
trans-unit.target: When your app calls the new [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) method overload, your app provides both an *OfferId* and a [**ProductPurchaseDisplayProperties**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263390) object populated with the name of the in-app product.

trans-unit.source: Report fulfillment of the in-app offer
trans-unit.target: Report fulfillment of the in-app offer

trans-unit.source: Your app will need to report product fulfillment to the Store as soon as the offer has been fulfilled locally.
trans-unit.target: Your app will need to report product fulfillment to the Store as soon as the offer has been fulfilled locally.

trans-unit.source: In a large catalog scenario, if your app does not report offer fulfillment, the user will be unable to purchase any in-app offers using that same Store product listing.
trans-unit.target: In a large catalog scenario, if your app does not report offer fulfillment, the user will be unable to purchase any in-app offers using that same Store product listing.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned earlier, the Store only uses provided offer info to populate the [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392), and does not create a persistent association between a large catalog offer and Store product listing.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned earlier, the Store only uses provided offer info to populate the [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392), and does not create a persistent association between a large catalog offer and Store product listing.

trans-unit.source: As a result you need to track user entitlement for products, and provide product-specific context (such as the name of the item being purchased or details about it) to the user outside of the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) operation.
trans-unit.target: As a result you need to track user entitlement for products, and provide product-specific context (such as the name of the item being purchased or details about it) to the user outside of the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263382) operation.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates the fulfillment call, and a UI messaging pattern in which the specific offer info is inserted.
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates the fulfillment call, and a UI messaging pattern in which the specific offer info is inserted.

trans-unit.source: In the absence of that specific product info, the example uses info from the product [**ListingInformation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br225163).
trans-unit.target: In the absence of that specific product info, the example uses info from the product [**ListingInformation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br225163).
